awd_titl_txt: Speculative Urbanism: Land, Livelihoods, and Finance Capital
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates a high-profile policy issue of considerable relevance to the US and countries worldwide: Are the major land transformations underway in rapidly growing metropolises helping to reduce urban poverty and increase urban sustainability? Aimed at enhancing economic competitiveness and reducing poverty in rapidly growing and densely populated cities of the Third World, this so-called "global cities" model of urban development strives to transform mega-cities (cities with populations of 10 to 20+ million) into "world-class" cities with matching infrastructure and amenities. Using Bangalore and Jakarta as case studies, this project examines how governments, global policymakers, international banks, local financial and political entrepreneurs, land developers, and ordinary residents shape commercial real estate and infrastructure projects at the core of this ambition. Project outcomes include a systematic assessment of the "global city" model, an issue of vital importance to the United States as a matter of global security, since poverty and unemployment in Third World mega-cities reinforces south-north migration and raises the prospect of civil unrest in regions of growing economic and geopolitical significance. The project's collaborative and comparative research design will generate mutually beneficial knowledge and educational exchange, and cement lasting intellectual relationships among US, Indian, and Indonesian higher education institutions. The project also enhances student training and expertise and integrates research results into university courses at the participating institutions. Investigators will broadly disseminate the results of this research in publications and through workshops for policy makers and government officials, and at public forums for urban planners, civil society groups and city residents.

Key to the "global city" approach is the conversion of purportedly "under-utilized" land into commercially generative tracts using innovative administrative and financial arrangements that connect foreign investors and institutions with local counterparts. In spite of a policy consensus that the "global city" template reflects current best practice for transforming mega-cities into economic growth engines, mitigating urban poverty, and achieving urban sustainability, the persistence of youth unemployment, jobless growth, widespread impoverishment, and environmental hazards (such as air and water pollution, mosquito-borne ailments, poor sewage and sanitation) in such cities raises the possibility that this prevalent model of urban transformation is not working as envisioned. In order to study whether and why this might be the case, the project investigates three interlinked processes: 1) the networks and mechanisms through which land is acquired, consolidated, and transformed into a market commodity for large-scale real estate and infrastructure projects, asking who is able to participate in the land market and who is not; 2) how policy and financial networks influence the implementation of the "global city" approach; and 3) whether this model of urban transformation ultimately disadvantages more people than it advantages, undermining urban livelihood and employment possibilities. The investigators employ a mix of qualitative and quantitative research methods, including policy evaluation and analysis of census and remote sensing data, as well as interviews with urban residents and key actors in two Asian mega-cities, to meet this tripartite scholarly objective.

por.por_cntn:
Are the major transformations seen across Asia's rapidly growing cities, informed by the "global city" model, fostering economic growth, urban sustainability and equity? These are urgent economic and geopolitical questions, given Asia's rising importance in global development in the context of climate change. 

The "global city" model, embraced across the Global South, views urbanization as key to economic development. This policy approach hinges on the conversion of purportedly "under-utilized" land into profitable commercial and residential real estate and "world-class" infrastructure, using innovative administrative and financial arrangements that connect international and national investors and institutions with local governments and property developers. 

How is the "global city" approach working in practice? Our multi-year, multi-sited research project investigated this question through a comparative analysis of two fast-expanding Asian metropolises: Jakarta, Indonesia and Bangalore, India. To achieve a systematic understanding of urbanization processes, we studied land and socioeconomic transformations in central and peripheral areas of these mega-cities. Our findings raise questions about the costs and benefits of current patterns of urbanization in the global South. 

We discovered that the modalities through which land is acquired and funds mobilized for real estate and infrastructure development differ due to the distinct economic and political trajectories of Indonesia and India. Yet, the outcomes of the "global city" model show striking similarities. Some key findings:

  • The build-up of "world-class" real estate and infrastructure has benefited the emergent middle classes in these cities; but at the cost of displacing poorer residents in central city areas as well as farmers in peri-urban villages, groups that have limited capacity to defend or leverage their property claims in the face of pressures from property developers, political power-brokers, and city administrators to acquire their land.

  • Real estate booms have fueled property speculation by individual and institutional investors, reinforcing an imbalance in urban housing by encouraging an over-supply of high-end residential units (in which prospects of speculative gain are highest) and an under-supply of affordable housing for low-income residents.

  • The paucity of housing for the burgeoning class of low-end urban service workers, who cater to the lifestyles of middle class and affluent residents in these cities, has ignited a secondary speculative market in rental properties. In central city areas, these "petit" landlords are small property holders of limited means (including slum residents) who creatively marshal funds to build rental units -- a gamble that can yield windfall incomes or crushing debt. In peri-urban Bangalore the new rental economy catering to migrant workers is primarily directed by farmers who sold land to real estate developers, while in Jakarta it is residents of informal settlements who speculate on land sales and the construction of rental housing. 

  • Economic speculation also underwrites socio-cultural speculation, as residents strive for distinctly different urban futures.

  • While some residents have benefited from these rapid urban changes, the focus on creating "world-class" real estate and infrastructure to attract capital investments has also widened inequalities and exacerbated the precarity of the urban poor.

  • The "global city" model of urbanization has had deleterious environmental impacts in both cities. Rapid and often unregulated real estate development, fostered by opaque urban planning procedures, informal alliances between political power brokers and developers, and jurisdictional conflicts is creating cities that are ecologically unsustainable. Traffic congestion, air pollution, depleted groundwater supplies, land subsidence, and recurrent flooding are some of the most visible consequences of untrammeled urban development in Jakarta and Bangalore. 

  • While both cities now boast of several forms of "world-class" infrastructure and amenities, attracting investments and fostering growth in key sectors of the economy, the long-term ecological and social sustainability of this urban development model is questionable. Its exclusionary nature, marked by housing scarcity, rising rents, environmental burdens, and casualization of employment, makes life in these cities increasingly untenable for the majority of residents (especially rural migrants). 

  • The comparative design of our study, and our attention to variations in intra-urban dynamics between central and peripheral areas of these cities, reinforces the robustness of our findings. Although we found important context-specific differences in the pace and patterns of urbanization between Jakarta and Bangalore, we also discovered remarkable similarities in economic, social and environmental outcomes.  

  • Our study offers new ways of conceptualizing large-scale capital projects unfolding across urban (and rural) landscapes. We argue that practices of speculation are exacerbating existing social inequalities and ecological stress in cities, while also undermining the viability of agrarian livelihoods and ecologies of rural areas where land is being converted into real estate. Our research points to the need to reverse current global trends of rapid urban expansion through capital-intensive investment, and instead consider diverse, locally generated practices that can provide affordable housing and durable livelihoods, accessible public spaces, and sustainable ecologies for the majority of people in the global South. It also underscores the need for urban policies that are more climate-friendly and socially just.
